turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: I won't have you bringing strange young girls in for supper...  ...by candlelight, I suppose, in the cheap erotic fashion of young men with cheap, erotic minds!

turns.speaker: NORMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Mother, please...

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: And then what? After supper, music? Whispers?

turns.speaker: NORMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Mother, she's just a stranger... hungry, and the weather's bad...

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Mother, she's just a stranger!  As if men don't desire strangers, as if... oh, I refuse to speak of disgusting things because they disgust me! You understand, Boy?

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Go on, go tell her she'll not be appeasing her ugly appetite with my food... or my son! Or do I have to tell her, cause you don't have the guts? Huh, boy? You have the guts, boy?

turns.speaker: NORMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Shut up! Shut up!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: They thought she'd be coming to me.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Left Phoenix under her own steam?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: From what?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Everyone concerned thought... if they could get her to give back the money... they could avoid involving her with the police.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Explains the private detective. He traced her to the Bates place.  What'd he exactly say when he called you?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He was out when I was there. If he's back he probably isn't even in bed yet.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: He wasn't out when you were there. He just wasn't answering the door in the dead of night... like some people do. This fellow lives like a hermit...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Was that all?

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: This detective was out there and Norman told him about the girl and the detective thanked him and went away.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Now wait a minute, Sam. You sure you saw an old woman?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yes! In the house behind the motel. I pounded and called but she... just ignored me.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: And you want to tell me you saw Norman Bates' mother.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You didn't find anything.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Nothing. Here, let's clear the path.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No mother.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: You must've seen an illusion, Sam. Now, I know you're not the seeing- illusion type... But no woman was illusion there and I don't believe in ghosts, so there it is!

turns.speaker: 1ST EMBALMER
turns.text: By gosh, them stiffs are get- tin' heavier and more of 'em every day. They even got the coroner working overtime.

turns.speaker: 2ND EMBALMER
turns.text: Yeah, between the gangsters and the autos, we won't need another war to carry off the population.

turns.speaker: 1ST EMBALMER
turns.text: You didn't even mention the suicides. Did you notice the beaut that came in today?

turns.speaker: 2ND EMBALMER
turns.text: Did I?

turns.speaker: 1ST EMBALMER
turns.text: That's the one that's got the coroner doing nightwork.

turns.speaker: 2ND EMBALMER
turns.text: What--special autopsy?

turns.speaker: 2ND OFFICER
turns.text: Imagine--she was alive. What a horror. Could have been buried alive. She must have run away from the morgue.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Never mind your theories. Was she ever conscious?

turns.speaker: 2ND OFFICER
turns.text: Just before she died she came to--

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Did she talk?

turns.speaker: 2ND OFFICER
turns.text: Said "doctor"--[something]

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: [Was it] "Meirschultz"?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Did you wish to see someone?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I understand my husband is-- your assistant. May I see him please?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: You mean he doesn't work for you?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: No, not exactly. Why the great anxiety? It must be something important.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: It is--you know what a struggle he's had.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Indeed, he has often told me.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: He's inherited a fortune.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: You say a fortune. He never spoke to me of any rich relatives.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: He hardly knew of them him- self.  I believe it was his uncle in Australia.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: I am certainly glad to hear it. I know he'll be pleased.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Don't tell him. I want to be the first to bring him the news.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: That's only natural. Maxwell will be here around eight tonight.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Okay--I'll be here at eight.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Gosh, you had me fooled.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Sh--sh--I want to have a few words with you quietly.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: So--friendly or otherwise--?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: [Perfectly friendly, my dear.] At last, I have really a secure living for us. We can travel or anything we choose.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Then you knew of the inheritance?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Sure--I have one little job to accomplish, then we can leave together. No doubt you are surprised at this disguise.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: No, I wouldn't be surprised at anything from you. Winningly. MAXWELL Now, honey--you are here in time to help me and you can--

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I knew there was a catch in this some place--but spill it. Quiet and dramatic. MAXWELL In the other room, I have a crazy woman that I have been treating.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Ha ha, <U>you</U> have been treating.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Quiet, will you? This is ser- ious. Our lives are in danger.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: What do you mean "our"?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: That's what I said. Now, lis- ten to me. I want you to help me take this woman down stairs. I will give her a shot. You can take care of her till I get help.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: How about me getting the help. She's quiet now, isn't she?

turns.speaker: BUCKLEY
turns.text: No-

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Who are you? What is your name?

turns.speaker: BUCKLEY
turns.text: I don't know, [I tell you].

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: What made you steal? Are you hungry?

turns.speaker: BUCKLEY
turns.text: No--I don't want to give any money. Everybody wants money--I'm not going to give any money.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Who wants your money-- maybe I can help you.

turns.speaker: BUCKLEY
turns.text: Maybe you want my money, too.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: No, I don't want money. I only want to find out who you are and where you live. My business is finding peo- ple. Not taking their money.

turns.speaker: BUCKLEY
turns.text: You--a friend to me?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Why, yes, to you, Mr.--Mr. --what?

turns.speaker: BUCKLEY
turns.text: I don't know--I can't tell--

turns.speaker: BUCKLEY
turns.text: No, no! I won't sign any pa- pers. You can't make me--

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Hm--pressure-- To Buckley. That's all right. We'll talk later.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Tell me, just what you know of Dr. Meirschultz.

turns.speaker: BUCKLEY
turns.text: Papers--they all want me to sign papers.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Dr. Meirschultz, too?

turns.speaker: BUCKLEY
turns.text: Yes--I can't stand it-- everybody wants papers-- oh, oh

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Take him to the psychopathic hospital.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Sure--they're sorta queer, I'd say. They's lots of queer goings on up there. They even brought a dog back to life once.

turns.speaker: COLLINS
turns.text: That sounds to me very remarkable.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: It may be, but to my notion, those that monkeys with what they got no business to get queer sooner or later.

turns.speaker: COLLINS
turns.text: Maybe you're right.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: I know I am. Why, I even heard a shot up there last night.

turns.speaker: COLLINS
turns.text: Why didn't you notify the police?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: I understand from your neighbors that all [them] cats are making noise at night. Dr. Meirschultz has put in a complaint.

turns.speaker: GOOF
turns.text: He's been stealing my cats to experiment on [them]. I know cause I've been [watching] spying on him.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: [Lot of] How many cats you have--what's the matter-- rats?

turns.speaker: GOOF
turns.text: Yeah--thousands, and right in my back yard.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Thousands?

turns.speaker: GOOF
turns.text: Sure, got thousand cats, too. Look at 'em-- Points to cages of cats.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: What' s the idea [of wanting so many] do you sell them [to the doctor]?

turns.speaker: GOOF
turns.text: Oh, no. It's my own idea. I'm in the business. In the fur business.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Oh, I see. Cats' fur.

turns.speaker: GOOF
turns.text: That's it. You get it quick.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: But where do the rats come in?

turns.speaker: GOOF
turns.text: You're not as quick as I thought. I figgered out that rats breed faster than cats-- cat skins make good fur-- The cats eat rats. Rats eat raw meat. That is, they eat the carcasses of the cats. So --the cats eat the rats--the rats eat the cats. And I get the skins--simple ain't it?

turns.speaker: GOOF
turns.text: Oh, him. He has a cat of his own. But his assistant--he's the cat-hatenest man I ever saw. Goofy, if ya ast me.]

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: By the way--did you hear a shot last night?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: I'm detective Jones. Just dropped in to tell you a bit of news.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: You found Buckley?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: By the way, where <U>is</U> your assistant?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Oh, Maxwell? He's left.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: How do you do.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Well, news of Buckley?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Yeah, he was picked up-- also the body from the morgue. Say, what did you have to do with stealing that body?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Why, Buckley stole that body. That's what alarmed Mrs. Buckley so. I have been try- ing to get her to put Buckley in an institution but she wants to keep him.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: So--that's it. Buckley took the body.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Yes indeed. He has been a <U>difficult</U> case. Now that <U>you</U> have him in custody--you have him haven't you?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Oh, yes, he's in good hands now.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Fine. Mrs. Buckley will be all right when she gets used to the idea.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Do you have many patients, doctor?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Oh no. Mostly research in endocrinology.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Mind if I look around? Seems to me you have car- ried on some interesting experiments. Sure of himself but taking no chances. MAXWELL Sure, I'll take you thru.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: What's down there?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Oh, just the basement. Some day I intend to build an experimental laboratory down there. It will save me from intrusion.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: I'd like to have a look.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: You here again?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Yes. Mr. Buckley thinks you treated him a little rough. He's in the hospital. How about it?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Oh, nothing. He is crazy, that's all. I had a little trouble with him.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Oh, nothing. A cou- ple of my patients having a little argument.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Take me down there.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: It won't do any good. They are a pair of would-be mur- deresses fighting it out.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Man, you're crazy. What kind of a place is this?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Oh, <U>I'm</U> crazy, am I? Let me tell you something.  Those women have--the gleam--

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Come on, we're wasting time.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
turns.text: Dr. Meirschultz, please.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: He isn't here.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
turns.text: I'm going to call the police.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: No, you can't do that--they'll get suspicious--

turns.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
turns.text: You can't double-cross me like that.  You were to help me. You were to operate on him. You were going to put him under my power.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Not so fast, Mrs. Buckley. That was your idea!

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: You are right. But before I can get him back here, you will have to help me.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
turns.text: How? What can I do?

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: [Something very important. I have been threatened;] Mrs. Maxwell, my assistant's wife, is crazy.  She thinks I mur- dered her husband. [She wants to murder me.] I want you to help me quiet her-- give her a shot from this hypo. [Keep it hid till we get her] down in the basement-- there is a secret vault [there]. We will put her there till we get your husband--[then turn her over to the authorities. Then we will both be free.]

turns.speaker: MRS. BUCKLEY
turns.text: It sounds all right, except for the fact that she's crazy. It seems to me she has the right idea--.

turns.speaker: MAXWELL
turns.text: Oh, so you feel that way too . Motions to other room. Stay in there--I'll call you when needed.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: NIKOLAS
turns.text: The wound is bleeding!

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Go to sleep!

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: What is it now?

turns.speaker: NIKOLAS
turns.text: I'm losing my blood!

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You're losing your blood?

turns.speaker: NIKOLAS
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Nonsense! ... It's here! ... Your blood ...

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: What were you dreaming about?

turns.speaker: LÉONE
turns.text: A voice ...

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: That spoke to you?

turns.speaker: LÉONE
turns.text: That called ... commanded ...

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: What did it say?

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Your father?

turns.speaker: LÉONE
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: The master ... is asleep!

turns.speaker: MARC
turns.text: Did you hear?

turns.speaker: NIKOLAS
turns.text: Yes, the child ...

turns.speaker: MARC
turns.text: The child!

turns.speaker: NIKOLAS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARC
turns.text: There's no child here.

turns.speaker: NIKOLAS
turns.text: But ... the dogs...

turns.speaker: MARC
turns.text: There's no child here, and no dogs either.

turns.speaker: NIKOLAS
turns.text: No?

turns.speaker: MARC
turns.text: No!  Good night!

turns.speaker: THE SICK-ROOM
turns.text: By the time we return there, all the preparations for the blood transfusion are completed.

turns.speaker: THE DRAWING-ROOM
turns.text: Joseph returns from the room where Gisèle is. He has evidently succeeded in calming her. He goes and sits in the chair where Nikolas sat. He rests his head in his hand. He sees the open diary and begins reading it.

turns.speaker: THE SICK-ROOM
turns.text: The blood transfusion is now in progress. The only words are curt orders like: 'Now! - Quickly! - That's enough! - Give it to me! - Sit still!' etc.

turns.speaker: THE DRAWING-ROOM
turns.text: Joseph is reading the diary, which arouses his interest more and more. It is as if he finds a connection between what he reads and the fearful events that have taken place around him. An extract from the diary is shown.

turns.speaker: THE SICK-ROOM
turns.text: The blood transfusion continues. Marc has positioned himself outside the circle of light from the lamp, so that he can see Nikolas in bright light, while he himself sits in the dark. Nikolas watches Léone's face anxiously and closely during her struggle with death. Life slowly seems to return to her, and her breathing becomes more peaceful. She opens her eyes and looks at the people round her, but she is much too enfeebled to speak, and closes her eyes again. Marc keeps a close watch on Nikolas, who grows paler and paler. His eyes swivel slowly from Nikolas to the patient and back to Nikolas again.

turns.speaker: THE DRAWING-ROOM
turns.text: Another fragment of the diary is shown [having to do with vampires].

turns.speaker: THE SICK-ROOM
turns.text: The blood transfusion is completed. While Marc himself is looking after the patient, the nurse leads Nikolas into an adjoining room, where she makes him sit down and prepares his bandage. The doctor stands bending over Léone.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: You killed him!  Come on with the rest of it. You killed him!

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: No -- I didn't. It was Igor at the waxworks.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: But you were in on it -- you worked for him.

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: No -- the only thing I did for him was to keep track of the man named Worth that runs the place where you arrested me tonight.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: You lie!

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: It's Igor at the Wax Museum! You'll find your judge embalmed in wax! He's a statue of Voltaire, with all the other corpses! The whole place is a morgue -- do you hear? -- a morgue!

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Yes, why?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I wondered. Did he invite you to lunch, or did you invite him?

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I wish you wouldn't be so sarcastic about Ralph. He's the sweetest kid I know.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: What are you laughing at?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I just had a picture of you telling a landlady some day that you didn't have the rent, but Ralph is awful sweet.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I don't see any big-moneyed boys running after you.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I met one last night ... all the money this side of Peoria.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Did you? Where?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: In the can.  The hoosegow! Mrs. Winton's little boy. The Pawk Avenue Wintons, you know ... and plenty of do-re-mi.  He's in the jail-house now ...

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I don't have any affairs. What do you mean?

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I don't think you could have a real affair. You couldn't care for anyone.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I've been in love so many times my heart is calloused ... but I've never hit one with dough. This love-in-an-attic isn't my idea of a way to spend a pleasant afternoon.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I don't agree with you.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: All right, you raise the kids -- I'll raise the roof. I'd rather die with an athletic heart from shaking cocktails and bankers, than expire in a pan of dirty dish water.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: You would.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: He can look like a chimpanzee and act like an igorot but he must have dough -- plenty of dough.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: You think money is the only requisite. It happens that the poor people are happier.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Then marry Ralph ... you'll be the happiest couple in the world.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: But what about lunch?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I'll have it for supper.  So long.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: There's no hurry. It's early.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I can't convince the inner woman that we can wait. She's howling for a bit of ground beef before we drop in on Santa Claus and the other dummies. I've only had a cup of coffee since last night.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Why didn't you eat last night?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Ouch! Eat? You can do a solo if you don't step on it. I'm going to bow out on you.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: What's the rush? There's no first act. They'll all be there and we don't have to appear at any particular time.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I'm hungry. I'll eat the first child I see. And I've an appointment with young Winton at 8:30.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: You wouldn't get mixed up with that little rotter, would you?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: No? Give me a chance, baby. Money is music in my ears, and when his old man kicks off there'll be a million dollar tune.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: If you're going to be indiscreet, I wish you'd be a little more discreet about it. Rich men, like Winton, love you and leave you.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Yeah, but they leave you plenty.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Well, thank goodness, that's settled.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Disappoint me? Why, what do you mean, dear?

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Well, you see, the old chap is pretty anxious to open on schedule. All of his advertising announced the opening tonight.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Why, certainly, sir. My fiancée. Charlotte, may I present Mr. Igor.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Delighted, I'm sure.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: But why? She's the best friend I've got.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: She isn't anybody's friend, and I don't like you living with her. She's a bad influence.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Nonsense. She's one of the nicest girls I know.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: What's nice about her? ... a hard-boiled little gold digger.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I won't let you say that!

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Well, I do say it.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: She thinks it's funny to talk the way she does, but--

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Don't kid yourself -- she means it.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Are we going to have the same quarrel over again?

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: I'm not quarreling, only ...

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: You wouldn't have said that before you met her.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I'd call it stupid at any time.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Well, that's just how stupid I am. When you go riding, it will be with me. And if it's with someone else, you can make it a permanent arrangement.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: So that's the way it is?

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: That's the way I feel about it.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I'm glad you told me. Good night, Mr. Burton.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: If you will forgive this poor, crippled stump, my dear, I am very happy to know you.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Although you would be amused if I were to tell you that I knew you before you were born. Before this terrible thing happened to me ...  ... I made a very beautiful statue. Even if I had not met with this disaster, I could never have hoped to do anything finer, probably nothing quite so fine. And, my child, you are that figure come to life. I wonder, some time, would you pose for one of my sculptors who does very excellent work?

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I'd love to, at any time.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: We'll be coming to the opening.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: At any time. You will always be welcome.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: But I think these things are beautiful.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: They are.  My boy, I think you are right. Everyone is tired out today and now that we have seen my doors open in a new country, I am beginning to realize that I am a little tired myself. You can call that fellow in from the front. I think we'll close for the night.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Oh! Mr. Igor! -- I'm so glad you're here -- I don't know why I should be, but I was a little bit afraid.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Oh! So, my little friend, you have honored me by accepting my invitation of last night.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: No -- I -- wanted to speak to Ralph. We had a silly argument last night and I said something unkind.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Oh, you children, you happy children. You've quarreled and now you're going to be friends again. And that is as it should be. Never let any stupid misunderstandings come between you.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: But it was really my fault.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: And he will probably demand the life of anyone who agrees with you. Let him think it was his fault ... He should be along very shortly .. . But be very stern before you forgive him, especially if it is your fault  ...  While you're waiting for your friend, would you like to see some new figures I have downstairs?

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I'd love to.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Oh, please, Mr. Igor, I'm terribly ashamed. I shouldn't have put you to so much trouble.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: It is no trouble at all, my child. This is the strange, vicarious pleasure that remains for me -- to see others enjoy the beauty I used to create.  My footing is not too secure.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Let me go! Let me go!

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: We have found immortality, you and I. You must not be afraid.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Ralph! Ralph!

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Please, oh, please, I haven't done anything to hurt you.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: And I have no desire to hurt you. You will always be beautiful. Think, my child, in a thousand years you will be as lovely as you are now.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: What! What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: The body of Joan Gale!

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: Hello, Express. What's the idea, trying to outsmart the police?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I'm not kidding. Joan Gale's body is packed in the box in the basement, and I saw the most horrible thing down there.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: Are you giving me this straight?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Don't take my word for it. Get down there yourself and give a look.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Listen, copper, get a load of this. While you're chinning yourself on a bar rail, I run down this story ... my story. Consider yourself my assistant.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: What do you think I am?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Whatever you are, you're the only one of it.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: It happens that I'm the law.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: How quaint. But I can go any place you can.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Not a very good one, I guess. He wasn't like anything human. He hobbled and swayed like a monkey, and the face, from the glimpse I got of it in the light from the street, was like an African war mask.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: You mean he was colored?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I don't know what he was, but he made Frankenstein look like a lily!

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: Hey, what do you think you're doing? Put that stuff back!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Nothing doing. This is my percentage. You birds are going to get yours. And anyhow, I found this dump.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: As I live and breathe and wear spats ... the prince.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Been doing experiments with Scotch and soda again?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Where did you get the news item?  From a little bird?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Yeah.  Have a pleasant vacation?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Charming. More delightful people crippled.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Great. Consider yourself crippled -- financially. See if you can jar your charming friends loose from enough to eat on.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Meaning what?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: That you're a sure bet to place in the bread line. There's no room on this rag for the purely ornamental. You're easy on the eyes and pretty conceited about it.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: I'm through clowning. You're all washed up. Get out!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: What do you mean, you poor ham! This is New Year's!

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: All right, what about it? We get out a paper just the same. Did you ever stop to think of that?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Well, is it my fault if nothing happens?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: And how does one go about getting these human documents, may I inquire?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: That is none of our business.  But you bring me something for the next edition if it's only a recipe for spaghetti!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Quick, Watson, the cookbook!

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Well, ain't that a shame. Nice little chappie that wouldn't harm a fly ... everybody picking on the little fellow.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: If this kid was some unknown soda jerker, they wouldn't have pinched him. But he's George Winton and they're playing him up. It's a Roman holiday for every paper hat editor in New York.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Why the goose pimples? If he wasn't social register -- if it was somebody like me, you'd be trying to hang him.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I wouldn't be trying, beloved. I would hang him! And another thing, all this gaga about the body disappearing. Eight bodies have been stolen in New York within the last eighteen months. Doesn't it seem more reasonable to hook this up from that angle?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: And ruin a perfectly good story? Don't be silly.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: No, I mean it. I think this kid's entitled to a break.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: He's getting a break, ain't he? He's front page.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: You give me a pain!

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: I'm glad to hear it. When did you go in for crusading in the cause of justice? This lousy mug, with all the money in the world, has had two or three nasty affairs. He's kept out o' print because his great- grandfather was smarter than the Indians.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Well, anyway, he couldn't have copped that body -- he was in jail.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: You don't think he'd be sap enough to do the job himself. I hope they give him the works. Even if he didn't kill the kid, he's responsible for her death, and they can fry him any time without making me sore.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Well, I won't work on it from that angle.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Oh, you won't -- you were pretty tough about Judge Ramsey -- a little while ago --

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: And they never proved anything against him.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Except that he disappeared when things got too hot.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Or was bumped off by someone who was afraid of him.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Whooey -- he took a run-out powder.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Well, that's got nothing to do with this case. Can I handle this my way?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: You cannot. I'm still editor of this sheet.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: All right, you said I was fired. Well, I quit! Give the assignment to somebody else.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Hey, come here, Sob-sister!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Nope, I'm through!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: On the square, Jimmy, if you'd seen Winton down there -- I'm not holding a brief for him -- maybe he's a dirty pup, but he's scared and hysterical -- and so kinda dumb and worthless ...

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Great! ... If he's worthless we'll give him away as a bridge prize. Come on -- beat it. It's five o'clock. You need some sleep.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: No, there's another point I want to iron out.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Sleep on it ... we'll get it tomorrow.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Which one is me? The horse?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Get out of here.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Come in, Prussic Acid. What's on your mind?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I want to see the original pictures of Joan Gale.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Hey, Mattie, dig into the morgue and send up all the art you have on Joan Gale.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Well, why so mysterious! Come on, spill it.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: So you can give me an argument and tell me I'm wrong. Don't be sil, Kid.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I am right! I know I'm right!

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Well, no one would ever suspect it. You don't sound right.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Listen, Jim -- and if you wisecrack while I'm talking I'll crown you with the inkwell.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: All right, wise guy. Go ahead. Spill it.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Jim, there's a little hokey-pokey wax museum opening up down on 14th Street.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Now don't that call for an extra!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I asked you to keep your trap shut!

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Well, you can't blame a guy for getting a little breathless with a scoop like that.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: All right, you poor baboon, you can guess the rest of it!

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: No kiddin'. What's your idea?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Just this -- I got a look at that dump a little while ago and if they haven't got a wax figure of Joan Gale in that line-up, then I'm crazy.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: We'll grant that.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: What!

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: About the Gale girl, I mean. Where do we go from there? What of it?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Listen, Jo-jo. Does this mean anything to you? Joan Gale's body swiped from the morgue -- Did you ever hear of such a thing as a death mask?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: I used to be married to one.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: And it came to life and divorced you. I know all about that. Now my idea is this: Somebody swipes the girl's body, takes impression, makes a mold, produces wax figure ... Bingo! ... Peddles it to this old skate down there!

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Work that up into a comic strip and syndicate it.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Let it go.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Come down to earth. Do you think they would dare do anything like that? Don't you think they'd know that figure would be recognized? Shake your head real hard -- you'll be all right.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: All right, Master Mind.  But there's something cockeyed about that joint and I'm going to find out what it is.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Oh, by the way, another pet theory of yours just blew up.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: That dear, innocent Judge Ramsey that you were so sure got bumped off for knowing too much has been located in South America.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: No kiddin'?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Almost certain.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Almost! I'll still bet I'm right, and let you write your own ticket.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Mit me, kid. I've got a classic.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: You here again like an evil spirit to mar my happiness?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: This one's a story, but I'm not going to tell you what it is. Every time I tell you anything it goes haywire.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: What do you mean -- haywire? You start out after murderers and come back with three-for-a-dime bootleggers. You start to solve murder mysteries and break up crap games. You're grand! I'm for you! Stupendous!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Say, you're always razzing everything I do, but this is one time I'm in.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Go on, little girl, take your troubles somewhere else. I don't feel like talking to you.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Was there any art on Judge Ramsey?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: What goofy idea have you got now? Don't tell me you suspect Judge Ramsey of stealing the body.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I'm going to make you eat dirt, you soap bubble! I'm going to make you beg for somebody to help you let go!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Listen, stupid, could I do anything that would possibly meet with your approval?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Yes, you could. Cut out this rotten business and act like a lady. Marry me.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: That's what I said.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I'm going to get even with you, you dirty stiff! I'll do it!

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: Yes, sir. I got in the cab and it was layin' there on the floor.

turns.speaker: FIRST DETECTIVE
turns.text: Where were you going when you got in that cab?

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: I don't remember. Not so very far--

turns.speaker: FIRST DETECTIVE
turns.text: Don't remember what day that was, do you?

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: No, sir. About three months ago.

turns.speaker: FIRST DETECTIVE
turns.text: You didn't happen to be going to Worth's place, did you?

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: No, sir, I'm sure it wasn't there.

turns.speaker: FIRST DETECTIVE
turns.text: You used to go to Worth's place a whole lot. What makes you sure it wasn't there?

turns.speaker: SPARROW
turns.text: Well, maybe it was. I don't remember.  You got to do something for me, I can't stand it any longer -- I can't!

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Call the Homicide Squad!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: How's every little thing?

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Fine. You're the first reporter in here for two hours. You people seeing the old year out?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I'm people which the old year saw out. I'm canned, fired!

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: No kiddin'.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I've got to make news, if I have to bite a dog.  Hey, Kelly! Oh, mi gosh, even he walked out on me.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: I've got a story for you. You know the Joan Gale girl?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Yes, she committed suicide yesterday. That's not news. I heard about it last year.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Oh, yeah? Maybe she didn't commit suicide. She may have been murdered!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: No foolin' -- any suspect?

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Do you know George Winton?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Old Howard Winton's cub?

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: That's the one.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: They don't suspect him?

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Don't they? He's down at The Tombs right now.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Say, if you're stringin' me, Old-Timer ...

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Why would I string y'? They were sweeties until a month ago.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: What does that prove?

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Nothing. Only she may have tried to blackmail him. You know such things have happened. Anyway, he was at her apartment a few hours before she was found dead.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Hotcha! Saved, one job!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Make it snappy, Colonel.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: There's an autopsy ordered at Bellevue immediately. You better skip over there.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Don't give this to anybody else, will you?

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: It's all yours.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Where'd you get the stag hound?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: He's not a stag hound. His name is Kelly and he's a police dog.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: What do you mean police dog?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Plain-clothes man.  Come on, slaves, drink and be merry for tomorrow you might be appointed correspondent to Washington ... a fate worse than death.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Listen, Flo, cut it out. Hard-Tack is pretty sore.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Ain't that something. The mad monk of Manhattan. Here goes nothing.  Listen to the animal cracker roar like a lion.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: I told you he was a sore.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Stories scarcer than caviar at a street cleaner's banquet, and he says, bring me a yarn. All I have to do is get a story.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Here's a wow.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Fine, thanks.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Gee, honey-bunch, I'm sorry -- I'm going to have to disappoint you.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Don't worry -- she'll get used to it.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: He might get some publicity out of it.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: No use. He's a crab, I tell you.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Who? Old Santa Claus there? That's easy for anyone with my sex appeal. He's a pushover. Watch me stand that old dodo on his ear.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Nix, Flo -- he won't let you in and you'll only get me in Dutch.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Horsefeathers!

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: What are you people doing out in the middle of the night?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I'm after news, as usual. I wonder if it would be all right for me to slip in and look around your factory?

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: I guess so. But wouldn't it be better for you to wait until the old man's here?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Well, I'll tell you a secret. I kinda like the old gent and I'm trying to build a special Sunday Magazine story out of him. It might help him a whole lot. But that's a side issue -- something I do on my own time.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Gee, that's great. After the bad opening that night the old boy was pretty blue. This will pep him up. Have you told him about it?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: No. I wanted to do it without saying anything. I think he's worth it.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Ralph, come here a minute, will you?

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Better cut that out.  That's what happens to girls who bite their nails.  What's wrong?

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: Yeah. I suppose you people will crucify me for something I didn't do.  I didn't! You understand that! ... I didn't do it! She -- tried before --

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Come on, old man, that won't do. You know you're innocent until proven guilty.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: Yes, sure, that's fine. While I'm proving my innocence, you people are going to uncover every petty kid trick I ever did ... you're going to write editorials about every cocktail I ever drank. Anything that any sane, normal person might have done will have a sinister meaning, if I did it.  Go on! Get out! I don't want to talk to you!

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Listen, kid. You're in a tough spot, and you can make it a whole lot easier for yourself if you cut out the cry-baby stuff --

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: Cry-baby?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: That's what I said.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: My lawyers will be on the job in a little while, and I warn you people anything you print about me you've got to prove. Dad won't stand for--

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Your dad has stood for plenty. Now let's get down to cases. When did you see the Dale girl last?

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: For a few minutes the afternoon before -- before --

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Hmmm. Why didn't you tell that to the police?

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: They didn't give me a chance. We had a couple of drinks and she was all right then. She seemed happy.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Uh-huh. Do you remember what she said? What did you talk about?

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: She laughed and told me that we were being silly, that we didn't care for each other any more but we needn't hate each other ...  ... She said she wanted to be friends.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I see. Was that all she said?

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: We planned a trip for her. I was going to send her to Bermuda.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: You weren't going with her?

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: No.  Why didn't I take her out somewhere? But she was laughing and seemed so happy.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Well, let's get back to the case in hand. They ordered an autopsy and discovered her body had been stolen from the morgue.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: Stolen! What are you trying to do to me? ... You're working with the police! ... You're trying to make me say something that can be used against me! You're trying ...

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Hold on, hold on. I'm trying to help you, if you're on the square, and I think you are.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: Then why are you telling me a crazy lie? ...

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: That happens to be the truth.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: Who'd steal her body?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: That's what they're going to ask you.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: Now look here. It's not up to us to do our own detective work. I've had enough trouble over this matter. I don't want anything more to do with it.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: Not even if it gives you a clean bill of health?

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: Not even then. The police are the proper people to conduct this affair. Now if you've got any suspicions I'll drive you to the nearest police station.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: What! And let every rag in town grab a red-hot story? Not so you could notice it! Now, look, I want you to drive me around the corner and wait for me.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: I told you I didn't want to mix in it.

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: All right, brother. Then you can go to some nice warm place, and I don't mean California.

turns.speaker: WINTON
turns.text: Please. I'm sorry. I'll see it through. What do you want me to do?

turns.speaker: FLORENCE
turns.text: I told you what to do. Drive around the corner out of sight of the house. I want to get a closer look at the place.
